content: The federal K-12 education assistance legislation, starting from the IASA in 1994 to the NCLB in 2001, focused on granting flexibility to grantees. The NCLB expanded existing flexibility authorities and introduced new ones for state and local administration of federal K-12 education programs. This report outlines these authorizations for flexibility and will be updated periodically to reflect new developments and impacts. The report defines "flexibility" as the authority to waive federal program requirements for state or local aid recipients meeting eligibility criteria. This includes consolidating programs, transferring funds, and waiving specific requirements under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act. The report focuses on federal involvement in K-12 education through the Elementary and Secondary Education Act (ESEA), excluding the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA). The ESEA programs are authorized through FY2008, with discussions on potential amendments and extensions by the 110th Congress. The report will be regularly updated to reflect legislative developments. It reviews federal K-12 education program requirements, sources, purposes, and concerns expressed by some stakeholders. The report discusses federal K-12 education program requirements, sources, purposes, and concerns expressed by stakeholders. It also covers special flexibility authorities that allow for waivers of certain requirements. Federal K-12 education programs have accountability requirements to ensure funds are used appropriately, with flexibility in areas like eligibility and allocation. These programs focus on student populations with special needs, such as disadvantaged or limited English proficient students. Federal K-12 education programs target student populations with special needs, specific instructional services, innovative approaches, and subject areas. These programs are often referred to as "categorical" programs due to their focused nature. The ESEA Title V-A Innovative Programs authority is considered a "block grant" due to its broad range of activities. Federal requirements or guidance to recipients of federal aid can be categorized as "requirements" or "non-regulatory policy guidance." "Requirements" must be met by grantees as a matter of law, derived from the authorizing statute or other federal statutes. Program regulations are published in the Federal Register. Program regulations, published in the Federal Register and integrated into the Code of Federal Regulations, supplement statutory language for complex issues prioritized by the U.S. Department of Education. Non-regulatory policy guidance is also provided for many programs by ED. The U.S. Department of Education issues program regulations in the Federal Register and Code of Federal Regulations. Additionally, non-regulatory policy guidance is published for many programs, including "Dear Colleague" letters and Q&A documents. Grantees are not legally required to follow this guidance, but may perceive it as reducing challenges to their use of federal aid. Grantees often view non-regulatory guidance as equivalent to regulations, especially in competitive grant programs where certain priorities are set by the Department of Education. While not mandatory, following these priorities increases the chances of receiving support. The Department of Education sets priorities for grant programs, especially for applicants from low-income families. These priorities, published in the Federal Register, are not mandatory but increase the likelihood of receiving support. In recent years, there has been a trend towards less voluminous regulations for federal education programs, with some programs having no regulations at all. Non-regulatory policy guidance is often provided instead. The Department of Education provides non-regulatory policy guidance for ESEA programs, with regulations being briefer and addressing fewer issues since the early 1990s. For example, regulations for ESEA Title I-A focus on standards, assessments, accountability, schoolwide programs, private school participation, and fund allocation. The trend towards minimal regulations continued after the NCLB of 2001, with the Department regulating only when necessary. The Department of Education intends to regulate only if absolutely necessary, focusing on nonregulatory guidance for Title I programs to provide flexibility and clarification. This guidance informs schools, parents, and other parties about different approaches to meet program goals for K-12 education assistance. The federal elementary and secondary education program requirements aim to establish accountability for appropriate use of federal aid funds. This includes target accountability, outcome accountability, and fiscal accountability to ensure funds are focused on eligible localities, improve student achievement, and assure financial responsibility. The federal elementary and secondary education program requirements focus on improving student achievement, enhancing K-12 instruction, and ensuring fiscal accountability by assuring financial integrity and preventing the replacement of state or local funds with federal aid funds. Specific requirements include targeting resources to high-need pupil groups, limiting fund uses to high priority services, conducting audits, enhancing parental participation, implementing staff qualifications, and providing equitable treatment for pupils in non-public schools. The federal elementary and secondary education program requirements focus on improving student achievement, enhancing K-12 instruction, ensuring fiscal accountability, targeting resources to high-need pupil groups, limiting fund uses to high priority services, conducting audits, enhancing parental participation, implementing staff qualifications, providing equitable treatment for pupils in non-public schools, and evaluating the effectiveness of federally supported instructional services. Grantees that violate regulations may have to repay funds or face sanctions, although these are rarely imposed. Additional general requirements apply to all recipients of federal education assistance. Federal education assistance recipients must adhere to program-specific and general requirements outlined in regulations such as EDGAR and OMB circulars. Additional regulations cover civil rights, student privacy, and compliance with child nutrition programs. Other federal agency regulations may also apply, such as those related to workplace safety and environmental protection for LEAs and schools. State and local educational agencies have wide discretion in using federal education assistance, with regulations from federal agencies other than ED applying to LEAs and schools as employers. Complaints about specific requirements often focus on selected types, leaving room for state and LEA discretion in areas such as grade levels, subject areas, and instructional techniques. Complaints about ESEA and related program-specific requirements often focus on prohibitions against commingling funds, restrictions on resource use, targeting aid, eligibility thresholds for flexibility, and outcome accountability under NCLB. These requirements aim to establish fiscal accountability. The NCLB establishes outcome accountability requirements to focus federal funds on students with the greatest needs and improve education services. Coordination between special program instruction and regular instruction may be challenging in low enrollment LEAs with small grants. The traditional federal categorical approach in education has been criticized for leading to fragmented instruction and focusing more on targeting resources rather than improving achievement for pupils with multiple special needs. Difficulties may arise from implementing federal programs in states with varying educational policies and demographic conditions. Various authorities allow waivers for federal K-12 program requirements, with limitations on types of requirements, programs affected, and eligibility. Waivers can be requested on a case-by-case basis or through blanket authority, with varying levels of additional accountability. Some federal authorities provide flexibility in the use of funds for education programs, with different levels of accountability. Five types of special flexibility include Ed-Flex, Secretarial case-by-case waivers, schoolwide program authority under ESEA Title I-A, Innovative Programs block grant, and flexibility for small, rural LEAs. These authorities were established before the NCLB of 2001. The Ed-Flex authority allows the Department of Education to delegate waiver authority to states for certain ESEA programs. Initially authorized for six states in 1994, it was expanded to 12 states in 1996 and later modified in 1999. The cap on participating states was removed, and technical amendments were made in 2001. In 2006, legislation extended Ed-Flex authority until the next reauthorization of ESEA Title I, Part A. Legislation in 2006 extended Ed-Flex authority until the next reauthorization of ESEA Title I, Part A (P.L. 109-211). The original Ed-Flex authority was granted to 12 states, with 10 states obtaining Ed-Flex status under P.L. 106-25. No state has been granted Ed-Flex authority since January 2002, and the authority for ED to grant Ed-Flex authority to additional states expired in FY2004. Ed-Flex authority is granted to a state for up to five years, and recent congressional action (P.L. 109-211) addressed the expiration of authority for the 10 Ed-Flex states by January 2007. Under P.L. 109-211, all 10 Ed-Flex states retain their authority until ESEA Title I, Part A is reauthorized. Another type of federal education program flexibility authority consists of waivers granted to SEAs or LEAs on a case-by-case basis by the U.S. Secretary of Education, with a focus on Title IX, Part D of the ESEA. The ESEA Title IX, Part D allows the Secretary of Education to waive requirements for educational programs. They believe that existing accountability requirements are crucial national priorities and that special flexibility lacks sufficient accountability provisions. Critics argue that special flexibility authorities lack accountability provisions and have been used for unproven purposes, raising concerns about their effectiveness in achieving national priorities.
